stem: The nurse is instructing a client on how to change an ostomy pouch. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Cut the skin barrier 1/16 to 1/8 inch larger than the stoma size.
Gently remove the old pouch and skin barrier using an adhesive remover.
Measure the stoma using the manufacturer's measurement guide.
Cleanse the peristomal skin with warm water (avoid soaps with oils).
Apply the new barrier and pouch, ensuring a leak-proof seal.

rationale.correct: Proper ostomy care prevents skin excoriation. (1) Careful removal preserves skin integrity. (2) Cleaning ensures a good stick for the new barrier. (3) Measurement is critical as stomas change size (especially post-op). (4) Cutting slightly larger prevents the barrier from cutting into the stoma while minimizing skin exposure to stool. (5) Final application.
rationale.incorrect: Cutting the barrier exactly the size of the stoma can cause constriction and ischemia to the stoma tissue.
clinicalPearls: The stoma should look moist, shiny, and 'beefy red'. A pale, blue, or black stoma is a surgical emergency.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Avoid recommending soap for ostomy care in your answers. Many soaps have oils/lotions that will cause the new bag to fall off within hours.

reviewUnits.heading: Ostomy Care and Patient Education
reviewUnits.body: Nurses educate on diet (low fiber initially) and 'gas-producing' foods. Pouch should be emptied when 1/3 to 1/2 full to prevent weight-related leaks.
